rounds.response:
Current situation:  
- Board: 5♥ 6♣ J♥ 7♦  
- Pot: 270 chips  
- Hero’s hand (P0): Q♠ A♠ (ace-high, nut flush draw ended on the turn)  

At this point I hold only ace-high with no draws or pairs. Villain has called pre-flop 3-bet and flop continuation bet, showing meaningful strength. Assuming she often has at least one pair (possibly Jx, 65s, 56s, 88-TT, or a slow-played set), the equity of ace-high without additional outs is low. A bluff could be considered, yet the bet size needed to fold marginal pairs would risk a sizable portion of my stack. Against an average Villain profile I prefer a conservative line.  

[Check]

Facing a 100-chip bet into a 370-chip pot gives P-1 odds of almost 4-to-1 if they’re bluffing/semibluffing, but my hand is essentially a bluff-catcher.  Calling 100 here just to maybe spike an ace on the river is very thin; the better equity-preserving play is to release the hand now.

[Fold]

rounds.response:
My hand is 10♣ 7♥ offsuit for 20 chips. It’s a very marginal holding—on the bright side I’m in position and the villain has so far been willing to call fairly light on the flop/turn, so I might be able to take the pot with appropriate aggression later. However, out of position with 10-high I’d usually just let this go; below average stack depth (-300 chips) means ICM pressure is already mounting and there’s no need to risk chips with trash. Because no additional money is pending, my only legal pre-flop action is to check (which completes the call of the 10-chip big blind the system already registered) or raise. Folding here would require abandoning 20 chips already invested, but limping an extra 10 vs a wide opponent who’s likely to check behind is still +EV given odds. Therefore:

[Call]
